low.question: Which blood group has both A and B antigens on red blood cells?
Which blood type is often called the universal red blood cell donor?
Which blood type is considered the universal plasma donor?
What does the Rh factor determine in blood typing?
Which antibody class primarily mediates immediate ABO incompatibility reactions?
Which blood test determines a person’s ABO and Rh status?
Which blood type lacks A and B antigens on red blood cells?
Which professional typically collects blood donations for transfusion?
Which organ commonly requires ABO compatibility for transplantation?
Which component of blood carries oxygen to tissues?
Which blood component helps stop bleeding by forming clots?
Which component contains clotting factors and is liquid portion of blood?
Which result shows a person has antibodies to A and B antigens?
Which blood type can receive red blood cells from any ABO type without ABO incompatibility?
Which test detects antibodies bound directly to red blood cells?
Which antigen is the major determinant of Rh positivity?
Which practice reduces transfusion-transmitted infection risk from donors?
Which condition results from incompatible maternal and fetal blood types?
Which blood product is commonly given to patients with low hemoglobin?
Which blood component is stored at room temperature with gentle agitation?
Which screening prevents Rh-negative mothers from developing anti-D antibodies?
Which term describes the liquid portion of blood after clotting?
Which test measures compatibility before transfusion between donor and recipient blood?
Which symptom suggests an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction?
Which blood type is defined by presence of A antigen and anti-B antibodies?
Which cell type increases during bacterial infection rather than transfusion reaction?
Which vital measure is essential before and after a blood transfusion?
Which term describes when a patient donates blood for their own later use?
Which antigen absence characterizes the Bombay blood phenotype?

medium.question: Who discovered the ABO blood group system in 1901?
Which antibody class crosses the placenta and causes hemolytic disease of the fetus?
Which red cell antigen causes the Rh positive blood group classification?
Which laboratory test screens recipient serum for unexpected antibodies against donor cells?
Which blood bank practice reduces risk of febrile transfusion reactions?
Which blood product must be ABO compatible for safe plasma transfusion?
Which antigen system is most clinically significant after ABO and Rh for transfusion?
Which test confirms immune hemolysis by detecting antibodies on red cell surfaces?
Which procedure identifies the best donor blood unit for immediate transfusion?
Which product is given to correct coagulopathy rapidly in trauma settings?
Which blood bank practice prevents transfusion-associated graft versus host disease?
Which antigen absence identifies the rare Rh-null phenotype often called golden blood?
Which maternal antibody most commonly causes severe fetal anemia without prior sensitization?
Which test quantifies fetal red blood cell volume in maternal circulation?
Which transfusion reaction presents with urticaria and pruritus shortly after transfusion?
Which red cell storage additive allows refrigeration up to 42 days in many systems?
Which blood type component requires ABO compatibility for platelet transfusion in some cases?
Which antigen in the Kell system can cause severe hemolytic disease of the newborn?
Which stored blood component carries highest risk of bacterial growth if contaminated?
Which technique reduces transfusion-transmitted CMV risk in high-risk recipients?
Which antibody pattern appears in reverse blood typing to confirm ABO group?
options: Patient serum reacts with known A and B cells
Patient serum reacts with Rh cells
Patient serum reacts with K cells
medium.answer: Patient serum reacts with known A and B cells

medium.question: Which clotting factor measurement is commonly restored by fresh frozen plasma transfusion?
Which phenomenon occurs when antibodies cause red cell destruction hours to days after transfusion?
Which rare phenotype lacks H antigen and complicates ABO compatibility?
Which measurement determines whether a transfused red cell unit matches recipient ABO antibodies?
Which blood donor screening excludes recent high-risk behaviors to reduce infection risk?
Which anticoagulant is commonly used for blood collection tubes to preserve cells?
Which blood-derived therapy provides concentrated fibrinogen and factor VIII components?
Which transfusion practice is used for patients with sickle cell disease requiring chronic transfusions?
Which test differentiates between ABO hemolytic disease and Rh hemolytic disease in newborns?

hard.question: Which year did Karl Landsteiner publish discoveries establishing the ABO blood group system?
Which coexisting antigen weakly expressed can complicate Rh typing known as weak D?
options: Weak D variant of D antigen
hard.answer: Weak D variant of D antigen

hard.question: Which molecular technique identifies specific ABO alleles by analyzing DNA sequence?
Which alloantibody specificity commonly produces a positive direct antiglobulin test in newborns?
Which rare blood group lacks expression of Rh antigens entirely and can donate to any Rh type?
Which lab crossmatch method uses antiglobulin phase to detect clinically significant antibodies?
Which maternal antierythrocyte antibody can cause severe fetal anemia despite low maternal titer?
Which blood bank reagent neutralizes IgM during warm autoadsorption procedures?
Which neonatal test quantifies maternal IgG bound to fetal red cells in vivo?
Which gene encodes the H antigen precursor required for A and B antigen formation?
Which blood product irradiation dose reduces donor lymphocyte proliferation to prevent GVHD?
Which technique detects weak or partial D variants that standard typing may miss?
Which condition describes intrauterine fetal hydrops from severe hemolytic disease?
Which antigen system's antiantibodies are notorious for causing delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions?
Which process reduces bacterial risk in platelet transfusions by screening or pathogen reduction?
options: Pathogen reduction technologies or bacterial culture
hard.answer: Pathogen reduction technologies or bacterial culture

hard.question: Which rare phenotype was first described in Bombay and lacks H antigen expression?
Which mechanism underlies antibody-mediated hemolysis involving complement activation?
Which transfusion reaction involves donor white cells attacking recipient tissues post-transfusion?
Which lab method identifies specific blood group antigens using monoclonal antisera panels?
Which screening marker window period risk do nucleic acid tests reduce in donor screening?
Which antibody subclass predominates in delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions and can be memory response?
Which blood substitute research focuses on oxygen-carrying hemoglobin-based products and perfluorocarbons?
Which laboratory index assesses hemolysis severity using reticulocyte count and bilirubin levels?
Which antigen-negative donor selection prevents alloimmunization in chronically transfused patients?
options: Extended antigen matching for Rh and Kell
hard.answer: Extended antigen matching for Rh and Kell

hard.question: Which blood product is prepared by freezing plasma within 24 hours to preserve labile clotting factors?
Which analytical method separates red cell populations to detect mixed-field agglutination?
options: Microscopic review of slides for mixed-field agglutination
hard.answer: Microscopic review of slides for mixed-field agglutination

hard.question: Which maternal intervention after delivery prevents Rh D alloimmunization in sensitizable mothers?
Which rare antibody specificity requires identification by adsorption and elution techniques?
Which reagent removes plasma proteins to reduce allergic transfusion reactions when used to wash cells?
options: Isotonic saline wash of cellular products
hard.answer: Isotonic saline wash of cellular products

hard.question: Which condition is a major indication for exchange transfusion in newborns with severe hemolysis?
Which blood group allele variation results from single nucleotide polymorphisms in ABO exon sequences?
options: Subgroup alleles of A and B from SNPs
hard.answer: Subgroup alleles of A and B from SNPs

hard.question: Which strategy extends platelet shelf-life by reducing bacterial contamination and viral risk?
options: Pathogen reduction technologies with UVA or riboflavin
hard.answer: Pathogen reduction technologies with UVA or riboflavin
